title: The 80/20 Rule for Field Reports
keyResearchPoints: Ericsson (1993): naive practice stops producing improvement after autonomous phase
Bjork (1994): 'desirable difficulties' — productive struggle improves long-term retention
Danaher: 'The lock is just the full stop at the end of a sentence. It's the sentence that counts.'
McGaugh / Zheng et al. (2022): emotional moments encoded via amygdala-hippocampal pathway
Cook & Crewther (2012): positive post-game feedback raises pre-game testosterone 28-51% for next game
Sweller: Cognitive Load Theory — working memory holds ~4-7 items, overload impairs encoding
Skilled Seducer: 'the 3 minutes before you lost her' concept
Ellis & Davidi (2005): reviewing successes AND failures beats failures alone
notes: Contract revised 2026-02-05. Previous contract was too broad ('Social Interactions'), structure was repetitive (7 sections → 4), and contained unverifiable claims (3-2-1 framework, Brian Cain as researcher). Convergence argument now the centerpiece. Danaher quote replaces generic 'off the move'. Bjork properly attributed (was conflated with Ericsson). Cook & Crewther finding added.

contract.title: The 80/20 Rule for Field Reports
titleAlternatives: Why Most of Your Field Report Teaches You Nothing
What BJJ Coaches, Neuroscientists, and Sports Psychologists All Agree On
contract.thesis: Learning from experience concentrates in a small number of specific moments. BJJ fight analysis, deliberate practice research, memory neuroscience, and sports psychology debriefing all converge independently: depth on the moments that mattered beats breadth across everything that happened.
contract.targetReader: Practitioners who debrief their sessions (or want to start) and are either spending too much effort documenting for too little insight, or not documenting at all because it feels overwhelming.
mustInclude: Ericsson's deliberate practice (correctly framed: improvement at edge of ability, naive practice automates)
Bjork's desirable difficulties (the actual source for 'productive struggle')
Danaher's 'full stop at the end of a sentence' quote (replaces generic 'off the move')
Emotional memory encoding — McGaugh, Zheng et al. 2022 (amygdala-hippocampal pathway)
Cook & Crewther (2012) testosterone finding (specific, surprising, verified)
Skilled Seducer's '3 minutes before you lost her'
Cognitive Load Theory for why exhaustive analysis fails
The convergence argument made explicit — multiple domains arriving at same conclusion
mustNotInclude: Brian Cain presented as researcher (he's a practitioner)
Unverified claims presented as peer-reviewed research
contract.tone: Research-backed, third-person. Authority from naming specific researchers with concrete findings. Alive and specific, not punchy and hollow.

sections.purpose: Cold open. 80% of a field report is filler. Pareto applies to learning from experience. ~150 words.
Core argument. Three independent domains (BJJ analysis, deliberate practice, field report practice) arrive at same conclusion. Danaher quote, Ericsson/Bjork, Skilled Seducer. ~400 words.
Why your brain already knows which moments matter. Emotional encoding (McGaugh/Zheng), Cook & Crewther testosterone finding, Cognitive Load Theory. ~300 words.
The practical shift. Which moment are you still thinking about? The 3 questions. Beginner caveat. ~200 words.
